channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: From @WSJopinion: If November’s election is dominated by the inflation question, Democrats won’t make it. Nothing Biden said Tuesday changed that, writes @KarlRove https://t.co/dejZLyfCns
Finland said it will seek parliamentary approval to join NATO, as Kyiv’s forces begin a counteroffensive toward the eastern city of Izyum https://t.co/z8aDLZ6Xj0

The suspected gunman in Saturday’s mass shooting in Buffalo was brought to a hospital by state police in June 2021 for a mental health evaluation after he made a generalized threat at his high school, officials said https://t.co/pW8ZzJE1Bz
As Elon Musk hits the pause button on his Twitter deal, questions arise as to why the Tesla chief is talking about phony accounts again now https://t.co/fTs2PzV93I
Saudi Aramco posted a record quarterly profit as the world’s most valuable company benefits from surging oil prices following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/7fsEppIhcO

“If it was one of us going to a predominantly white neighborhood, do you think they would have been alive right now?” Hundreds of people gathered for an impromptu vigil and rally Sunday in the Black Buffalo community targeted by a white mass shooter. https://t.co/Ay4lHU57v1

“She was a great mom. She was a staunch advocate for her family,” said the son of Ruth Whitfield, one of the victims of the Buffalo supermarket mass shooting. “She died doing what she did every day, which was caring for her family.” https://t.co/AtJLZU91Fc

Live updates: Officials are investigating the mass shooting that killed 10 people at a Buffalo supermarket as a possible hate crime; Tops Friendly Markets says it is "heartbroken over the senseless violence." https://t.co/YnD3akdswR https://t.co/JF8OZKAuzy

Officials are investigating the killing of 10 people at a Buffalo, N.Y., supermarket as a possible hate crime, citing a document linked to the shooter detailing a planned mass shooting with the goal of killing Black people https://t.co/0hbbZf87y1
Three Ukrainian brothers were taken from their homes, interrogated, beaten, shot and left for dead. One made it out alive. https://t.co/eWbcs8S8pI

Residents of recently Russian-occupied villages surrounding Kyiv are returning, removing debris from their rubble-strewn homes, planting vegetables and planning for the future. https://t.co/ulwqArI72W
Before deleting your Twitter, Facebook or Instagram account, here's what people who actually did it have to say about logging off for good https://t.co/GmG2UmNvDC
U.S. officials and allies around the world are looking to establish friendly supply routes for key goods amid a war and global pandemic https://t.co/LLWNxDsEsg
Kendrick Lamar’s new album “Mr. Morale and the Big Steppers” isn’t just about music. It is about starting a new chapter in his career: entrepreneur. https://t.co/OA4lmisYWL
Saudi Aramco posted a record quarterly profit as the world’s most valuable company benefits from surging oil prices following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/jIDdUn2cOx
As Elon Musk hits the pause button on his Twitter deal, questions arise as to why the Tesla chief is talking about phony accounts again now https://t.co/gmiy6Ht5Z5
El Salvador’s President Nayib Bukele went all in on bitcoin. The cryptocurrency’s steep losses are stoking fears of a debt default. https://t.co/cJ3cb02aEO

“Russia is much more unpredictable than we ever thought.” Helsinki’s security strategy was to prepare for invasion but placate Moscow by staying out of NATO. The Ukraine attack, echoing the 1939 Soviet assault of Finland, has upended the balance. https://t.co/0ctTYRl2Kb
Russia halted the export of electricity to Finland, days after Finland’s leaders said they supported an application for NATO membership. https://t.co/CeZ4oKsvq7
Watch: Intermittent fasting can help improve focus and brain health for animals, studies show. We explain how some of these cognitive benefits can also apply to humans. https://t.co/msrfUFoTkn
The return-to-work rebellion is getting serious, as employees push to make their remote arrangements permanent https://t.co/BOOwIa4LRC
Little-known candidate Kathy Barnette has surged into contention against Mehmet Oz and David McCormick ahead of Tuesday’s Pennsylvania Senate GOP primary https://t.co/pYnuSoh19N
Multiple people were shot Saturday afternoon at a supermarket in Buffalo, N.Y., police there tweeted, adding that the alleged shooter was in custody https://t.co/wKhfEMoDTA
The number of U.S. residents in Portugal climbed by 45% last year. Here's what to know about why so many Americans are making the country their home base. https://t.co/WNrAYGnDgp

From @WSJopinion: Americans have learned the hard way over the last two years that no amount of federal transfer payments can make up for the decline in real wages caused by inflation https://t.co/ivdGRDnlyI
Kaitlyn Younger applied to five Ivy League schools, plus Stanford and Berkeley, with a 1550 on her SAT. None accepted her. https://t.co/fEsIgDPKWM

The risk of electricity shortages is rising throughout the U.S. And electric-grid operators are warning of rolling blackouts during heat waves or other peak periods as soon as this year. https://t.co/R3zsS1iVuV
An image of the supermassive black hole at the center of our galaxy has been captured for the first time https://t.co/4BZ6XjWA3u

Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky is Jewish. Why did the Russian foreign minister compare him to Hitler? The answer lies in the Putin regime’s distorted view of World War II and Russian history. https://t.co/wOMtbYkgft
Residents of recently Russian-occupied villages surrounding Kyiv are returning, removing debris from their rubble-strewn homes, planting vegetables and planning for the future https://t.co/CFt2oPslAU
The return-to-work rebellion is getting serious, as employees push to make their remote arrangements permanent https://t.co/2QUOgcIZCI
TikTok brain is real, researchers say, and it’s affecting kids’ cognitive development. "We’ve made kids live in a candy store." https://t.co/moKlJzFbn4
Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology say they have found a potent new tool in the fight against global warming. It is basically cat litter. https://t.co/ui98uh8dcL
A GOP delegation led by Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell met with President Zelensky in Kyiv https://t.co/WXUlAbyJv8
More than 380 marches and events to rally for abortion rights are planned across the country Saturday https://t.co/Pbab8yqk0V
Ukraine began a counteroffensive toward the eastern city of Izyum, aiming to disrupt Russian supply lines into Donbas https://t.co/xsCmLRnmw7

“I have lost count of how many times we went to the cellar but that’s OK.” The first entry in Tymofiy Zozulia’s war diary was dated March 12. He didn't know yet that his mother and stepfather were already dead. https://t.co/mYQtCO5xoF

Obituary: Fred Ward, who acted in the movies “Tremors” and “The Right Stuff,” had a decadeslong career, with his first major role being in Clint Eastwood’s 1979 hit “Escape from Alcatraz” https://t.co/I0esCOL0id
Miami locals say they're fed up with relocating New Yorkers driving up apartment rent https://t.co/2xm3cAsX3z

Review: Can Ford electrify its bestselling family of vehicles in a way that still has mass appeal? With the debut of the F-150 Lightning, says car columnist Dan Neil, the answer is a resounding yes https://t.co/lIwwAstXMx
The helium is coming out of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies as investors become risk-averse. Charts show how, for crypto, it has been a volatile journey into the depths. https://t.co/40Y2LaerVw
Here is an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal's weekend edition https://t.co/XfxlohYF1V https://t.co/YNZmeJRBGi
Netflix has a new message for its employees: Be prepared to work on content you may not agree with. And if you don’t like that, you can quit. https://t.co/eXEnpaeU39
When Putin invaded Ukraine, he sought to divide and weaken NATO. Nowhere has that strategy backfired more than in Finland. https://t.co/W2vv2bwOCC
Usain Bolt was the fastest teenager in the world. American Erriyon Knighton is faster. https://t.co/tHg6SUqYdO

Early in their invasion of Ukraine, Russians had numbers on their side: the 3:1 rule, the ratio by which attackers must outnumber defenders in order to prevail. They may have placed too much faith in “force ratios,” @JoshZumbrun explains. https://t.co/1kMeiQ2Lq2

New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, who championed a zero Covid-19 strategy from early in the pandemic, has tested positive for the virus and will stay at home for a week https://t.co/FTjR6iOcNw

Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed al Nahyan, the second president of the United Arab Emirates and the ruler of Abu Dhabi who shunned the limelight even as he oversaw his country’s remarkable transformation, has died at 73 https://t.co/miNFccNkuq
“I cannot imagine my life without parents.” A Ukrainian boy recounts in his diary the loss of his mother and stepfather in an attack by Russian forces outside Kyiv. https://t.co/msOTVp9tdp

“Russia is much more unpredictable than we ever thought.” Finland worried about a Russian attack but chose to stay out of NATO. The Ukraine attack, echoing the 1939 Soviet invasion, suddenly changed the calculus. https://t.co/xibiIdLmSU
